raw_text:
Cyber criminals step up the pace
 
 So-called phishing attacks that try to trick people into handing over confidential details have boomed in 2004, say security experts.
 
 The number of phishing e-mail messages stopped by security firm MessageLabs has risen more than tenfold in less than 12 months. In 2004 it detected more than 18 million phishing e-mail messages. Other statistics show that in 2004 73% of all e-mail was spam and one in 16 messages were infected with a virus.
 
 In its end-of-year report, MessageLabs said that phishing had become the top security threat and most popular form of attack among cyber criminals. In September 2003, MessageLabs caught only 273 phishing e-mails that tried to make people visit fake versions of the websites run by real banks and financial organisations. But by September 2004 it was stopping more than two million phishing related e-mail messages per month. Worryingly, said the firm, phishing gangs were using increasingly sophisticated techniques to harvest useful information such as login details or personal data.
 
 Older attacks relied on users not spotting the fact that the site they were visiting was fake, but more recent phishing e-mails simply try to steal details as soon as a message is opened. Other phishing scams try to recruit innocent people into acting as middlemen for laundering money or goods bought with stolen credit cards. "E-mail security attacks remain unabated in their persistence and ferocity," said Mark Sunner, chief technology officer at MessageLabs. "In just 12 months phishing has firmly established itself as a threat to any organisation or individual conducting business online," he said. Mr Sunner said MessageLabs was starting to see some phishing attacks become very focused on one company or organisation. "Already particular businesses are threatened and blackmailed, indicating a shift from the random, scattergun approach, to customised attacks designed to take advantage of the perceived weaknesses of some businesses," he said. Although phishing attacks grew substantially throughout 2004, viruses and spam remain popular with cyber-criminals and vandals. One of the biggest outbreaks took place in January when the MyDoom virus started circulating. To date the company has caught more than 60 million copies of the virus. Also up this year was the amount of spam in circulation. In 2003 only 40% of messages were spam. But by the end of 2004, almost three-quarters of messages were junk.
llama3.2:1b: Cyber criminals have increased their attacks on individuals and businesses online, with phishing being a top security threat.
MessageLabs detected over 2 million phishing-related emails per month in September 2004, up from just 273 that year.
The number of phishing e-mail messages has risen by more than tenfold since then.
Phishing gangs have become increasingly sophisticated, stealing login details and personal data with their tactics.
llama3.2:3b: Phishing attacks have increased significantly in 2004, with over 18 million phishing e-mail messages detected by MessageLabs.
The number of phishing attacks has risen tenfold in less than a year, with phishing gangs using sophisticated techniques to harvest information such as login details and personal data.
Phishing attacks are becoming more focused on specific companies or organisations, and cybercriminals are also turning to viruses and spam to continue their malicious activities.
gemma2:2b: Phishing attacks increased significantly in 2004, becoming the most popular cybercriminal tactic and posing a major threat to online businesses and individuals.

The number of phishing emails detected by security firm MessageLabs has surged more than tenfold, and these attacks employ increasingly sophisticated techniques to steal sensitive information like login details.
While virus and spam remain prevalent threats, phishing attacks have shown a clear trend towards targeted attacks on specific companies or organizations.

The number of phishing e-mail messages detected by MessageLabs increased tenfold in less than a year, but the security situation is still not entirely clear as the threat remains constant.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Phishing attacks on e-mail have increased significantly over 12 months, involving more than two million phishing-related emails per month in September 2004 compared to just 273 in September 2003, becoming the top security threat and most popular form of attack for cyber criminals.
Phishers are using increasingly sophisticated techniques, including stealing login details or personal data as soon as a message is opened.
Cybercriminals continue to use viruses and spam despite phishing attacks growing substantially throughout 2004.
qwen2.5:3b: Cyber criminals have intensified phishing attacks significantly since 2003.
MessageLabs detected over 18 million phishing emails in 2004, marking a tenfold increase from previous years.
These attacks are now the primary security threat, targeting both individuals and organizations.
Phishing tactics have evolved, with attackers focusing on quickly stealing login details or personal information once messages are opened.
The number of spam emails also surged dramatically, nearly reaching three-quarters of all messages in 2004 compared to only half in 2003.
While phishing has established itself as a dominant threat, other forms of cyber attacks like viruses and spam still persist.
opencoder:1.5b: Cyber criminals have started to ramp up the pace in recent years.
So-called phishing attacks try to trick people into handing over confidential details and are increasingly common.
MessageLabs, a leading cybersecurity firm, has detected more than 18 million phishing e-mail messages since 2004.
The company reported that it was stopping more than two million phishing related e-mail messages per month in September 2003.
The phishing attacks have become the top security threat and are among the most common forms of cyber-crimes.
The phishing gangs have begun to exploit these techniques for gaining valuable information, such as login details or personal data.
Viral attacks like MyDoom, viruses and spam remain popular with cyber-criminals and vandals.
Despite this, they continue to grow significantly since MessageLabs caught more than 60 million copies of the virus in 2003.
The company's spam reports indicate that almost three-quarters of messages were junk since 2003.
smollm:1.7b: Cyber criminals step up the pace and phishing attacks have become more frequent and sophisticated.
The number of phishing e-mail messages has increased significantly in 2004 compared to 2003.
In fact, phishing attacks have become so common that they are now considered one of the most popular forms of cybercrime.
The statistics show that in 2004 more than 73% of all e-mail was spam and phishing attacks were responsible for more than 18 million of these messages.
This is a significant increase from 2003, when phishing attacks accounted for only about 27% of all email.
The most popular form of phishing attack in 2004 was the use of fake websites that looked like those run by real banks and financial organizations.
However, as time went on, cybercriminals began to use more sophisticated techniques to harvest useful information such as login details or personal data.
This is a significant shift from the older phishing attacks which relied on users not spotting the fact that the site they were visiting was fake.

The report also highlights the increasing sophistication of phishing gangs and their ability to recruit innocent people into acting as middlemen for laundering money or goods bought with stolen credit cards.
This is a clear indication that cybercriminals are becoming more targeted in their attacks, using social engineering techniques to trick victims into providing sensitive information.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: In 2004, phishing attacks became increasingly common among security experts, with MessageLabs stopping over tenfold more phishing e-mails than in 12 months.
They stopped nearly 18 million phishing messages, compared to only 273 in September 2003, and detected over two million monthly e-mails in September 2004.
Phishing had become the top threat, with 73% of all emails being spam and one in every sixteen messages infected with a virus.
Older attacks relied on users not spotting fake sites, while newer phishing e-mails targeted specific businesses to steal details.
Phishing gangs used sophisticated techniques to gather data like login details or personal information.
Mark Sunner noted that phishing has persisted strongly over 12 months and is now becoming specialized, targeting specific companies.
Viruses and spam remain popular despite claims of their decline in recent years, with almost three-quarters of messages considered junk by genuine users.
tinyllama:1.1b: During a period marked by increasing numbers of phishing e-mails and more sophisticated techniques used to harvest personal data, cyber criminal groups have stepped up their pace in attacking organizations and individuals online.

According to security expert Mark Sunner, the number of phishing attacks rose more than tenfold in 2004, and some businesses are now being targeted by customized attacks designed to take advantage of perceived weaknesses.
These attacks have become popular with cyber-criminals and vanalists alike, with virus and spam campaigns accounting for the majority of messages being caugh in 2004.

In that time, these malicious e-mails have become the most popular form of attack among cyber criminals.
Phishing is the practice of tricking victims into handing over confidential information, often by pretending to be an official organization or website.
This has led to increasingly sophisticated techniques being used to harvest useful data like login details and personal information.
As phishing attacks continue to evolve and become more targeted, MessageLabs is expecting the number of phishing messages detected in 2005 to rise even further.

Viruses and spam remain popular with cyber-criminals and vandals, with MyDoom virus alone infecting over 60 million copies in 20015.

Phishing gangs have also become more sophisticated in their techniques to steal useful information such as login details or personal data from innocent users.
These attacks are a significant threat to any organization or individual conducting business online, according to Mark Sunner, MessageLabs' chief technology officer.
Phishing attacks have firmly established themselves as a threat to any company or individual conducting business online.
While viruses and spam remain popular with cyber-criminals, phishing attacks grew significantly in 2004.
